case_vignette: A 26-year-old woman comes to the physician because of increasing pain and swelling in her right foot for the past 2 weeks. Initially, the pain was intermittent but it is now constant and she describes it as 8 out of 10 in intensity. She has not had any trauma to the foot or any previous problems with her joints. The pain has not allowed her to continue training for an upcoming marathon. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. She is a model and has to regularly wear stilettos for fashion shows. She appears healthy. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows swelling of the right forefoot. There is tenderness to palpation over the fifth metatarsal shaft. Pushing the fifth toe inwards produces pain. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I'm experiencing increasing pain and swelling in my right foot for the past 2 weeks.
Have you sustained any recent injuries to your foot?
No, I haven't had any injury to my foot.
Is the swelling localized to any specific area, such as the big toe, or is it spread throughout your foot?
The swelling is in the right forefoot.
Have you noticed any changes in skin color, or is there any warmth around the swollen area?
The vignette doesn't provide information on skin color changes or warmth, so I can't comment on that.
Have you experienced any similar issues with your foot or any other joints in the past?
No, I haven't had any previous problems with my joints.
Do you have any chronic medical conditions such as diabetes, or do you take any medication regularly?
I only take an oral contraceptive and have no chronic medical conditions.
Have you had any fever, chills or other systemic symptoms?
The vignette doesn't mention fever, chills, or other systemic symptoms, so I haven't experienced those.
Have you experienced any recent changes in your activity level or started a new exercise routine?
I have not been able to continue training for an upcoming marathon due to the pain.
Given your marathon training, has there been a change in your footwear or an increase in the intensity or duration of your training before the pain started?
The vignette does not provide details about a change in my footwear or a change in the intensity or duration of my training before the pain started.
Do you feel pain at rest, or does it worsen with activity?
The pain was intermittent but now it's constant.
Is there anyone in your family with similar foot problems or a history of arthritis or autoimmune diseases?
The vignette doesn't mention any family history of foot problems, arthritis, or autoimmune diseases.
Have you noticed any limitation in the range of motion or difficulty in bearing weight on the affected foot?
The vignette does not mention any limitation in range of motion or difficulty bearing weight.

Given the symptoms of forefoot pain and swelling without injury, absence of systemic symptoms, and no prior joint problems, considering the increased physical activity from marathon training, the most likely diagnosis would be a stress fracture or overuse injury until proven otherwise.

**Final Diagnosis:** Stress fracture or overuse injury of the foot.
